Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Single-Crystal X-ray Diffractometer for Chemical Crystallography Research and Training
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), Professor William Connick from the University of Cincinnati and colleagues Anna Gudmundsdottir, Jeanette Krause, James Mack II and Hairong Guan have acquired a dual source, microfocus single crystal X-ray diffractometer equipped with a photon detector and a cryogenic device. In general, an X-ray diffractometer allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles. It also provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules. The studies described here impact a number of areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate and graduate students in chemistry and biochemistry at this institution and regional collaborators. Additionally, the instrument exposes high school and undergraduate students to crystallography and research. Participation of underrepresented groups is enhanced through the principal investigator's involvement with ACS-Project SEED, Dreyfus, NSF-REU and Women in Science and Engineering programs.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) identifying efficient photoprocesses for storing energy via metal-complex photochemistry that releases two electrons per photon absorbed, (b) studying sensor materials to determine the mechanisms of colorimetric and luminescence-based responses of materials to chemical vapors and aqueous ions, (c) preparing and characterizing potential catalysts for chemical transformations and green technologies and (d) characterizing the underlying chemistry of agents that release reactive species that target specific substrates or are themselves components in metabolic pathways or nanostructured materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funds awarded to the University of Cincinnati (UC) by the National Science Foundation Major Research Instrumentation (NSF-MRI) program was used to purchase a Bruker D8 Venture diffractometer equipped with both copper and molybdenum micro-focus X-ray sources, Photon-II detector, and Oxford Cryostream liquid nitrogen low temperature device. The diffractometer is housed in the Department of Chemistry Richard C. Elder X-ray Crystallography Facility and is available to users across the UC campuses, other colleges and universities, and national or private sector laboratories.

 

This dual-source diffractometer has allowed us to analyze more challenging, environmentally-sensitive, and weakly-diffracting crystals that require greater X-ray flux, a highly-sensitive detector, or different wavelength options. Moreover, it has allowed us to pursue more time-consuming studies not previously practical. Structural information obtained from the diffractometer has enhanced research by positively impacting scientific disciplines such as chemistry, materials science, and medicinal chemistry. These disciplines rely on the spatial details of molecule(s) and their interactions with neighboring species such as other molecules, ions, or solvents.

 

Instruction and training with research-grade instrumentation are essential components of high-quality undergraduate and graduate education, which is necessary for building a nimble and innovative technical workforce. The diffractometer has enhanced experience-based scholarship and research-oriented training through its use in the curriculum. Graduate students are trained in single crystal X-ray diffraction through individual instruction or by enrolling in the annual graduate-level X-ray crystallography course. Training of undergraduate students in crystallography is accomplished either as part of a laboratory course or capstone project to complete the bachelor's degree requirement. High school and undergraduate students participating in summer programs, such as ACS-Project Seed, NSF-Research Experience for Undergraduates and WISE-Women in Science and Engineering, have access to the instrumentation if projects they are involved in require structure determination. The diffractometer is also used in various outreach activities encouraging more students to pursue degrees in STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) disciplines.
